Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. is committed to the safety of its employees and neighbors and operates the facility as a responsible member of the community. Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. encourages personnel to continually identify methods and procedures to reduce the use and risks associated with hazardous chemicals. This process includes protecting the community, environment, and personnel by implementing technology and procedures designed to reduce the impact of any potential release of flammable chemicals. This commitment to safety is documented in the policy and compliance manuals for this facility, which are available to all employees.

As part of Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.'s commitment to safe and environmentally friendly operations, monthly meetings are conducted with all employees as well as other more specific operational meetings concerning safety. Input and comments from plant personnel are also key aspects of Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.'s safety practices: By giving personnel the ability to make suggestions regarding safety and operational practices, the facility can operate efficiently and safely. Another key element in Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc.'s safety practices consists of the regular internal and third party environmental and safety audits. Matheson Tri-Gas recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia, chlorine, and arsine.  

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined in the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program for this facility.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling of highly hazardous chemicals. Written procedures have been developed for handling and inspecting the flammable processes.  The company training policy requires all empl

oyees to be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.  The facility's maintenance program requires periodic inspections of process and safety equipment to ensure they are in good condition.  Overall, our program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area.  

Incorporated into our program is our Emergency Action Plan (EAP), which details the response this facility will take as a result of an uncontrolled chemical release.  The EAP includes procedures for notification of local emergency responders.  The EAP is maintained current and updated periodically.

This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the process and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Matheson Tri-Gas, Inc. facility receives, stores, manufactures, and ships the following regulated chemicals: n-Butane, 1-Butene, Ethylene, Isobutane, Isopentane, Methane, n-Pentane, Propane, and Propylene.  The facility is located at 1401 Stauffer Road in Palm, PA.  

The following regulated RMP-regulated substances and maximum intended inventories are maintained onsite:
-	Propane: 127,867 lbs
-	Isobutane [Propane, 2-methyl]: 85,582 lbs
-	1-Butene: 44,883 lbs
-	Methane: 32,663 lbs
-	Propylene [1-Propene]: 238,040 lbs
-	Butane: 85,120 lbs
-	Ethylene [Ethene]: 69,299 lbs
-	Isopentane [Butane, 2-methyl-]: 47,840 lbs
-	Pentane: 28,903 lbs

Accidental Release Prevention Program

Matheson Tri-Gas has developed a Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program to manage the handling of the regulated substances. The program includes but is not limited to the following elements:

1) Safety information that describes the chemical hazards

dealing with chemical releases and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and outside emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for chemical exposure.  Employees perform evacuation drills and receive refresher training on the EAP.  In the event of a chemical release, the facility emergency coordinators will assess the situation and contact the fire department for assistance.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Process Hazard Analyses and Compliance Audits have been performed on the regulated processes, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Matheson Tri-Gas has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.
